content.webTitle: Shepard Fairey vandalism case 'disappoints' Detroit arts community

fields.headline: Shepard Fairey vandalism case 'disappoints' Detroit arts community
fields.bodyText: Detroit artists on Friday said the prosecution of Shepard Fairey was “disappointing” for the city, as a court set a date for the trial of the world-renowned street artist on charges regarding the alleged vandalization of several buildings. Fairey was in court for a brief scheduling conference, in a case in which the 45-year-old stands accused of causing more than $20,000 in damages during a visit to Detroit, some of it through the use of wheat paste to stick posters to building walls. In May, Fairey was invited by the billionaire Dan Gilbert to paint several murals in the city, including a 185ft mural on the soaring One Campus Martius building. The high-profile case has attracted international attention, particularly given the intense prosecution of a “quality of life” crime by a city that is still badly affected by violence. The mayor of Detroit, Mike Duggan, has long taken an adversarial stance against graffiti. He has said he expects the alleged vandalism by Fairey to be “investigated vigorously”. In a preliminary examination last month, Detroit police sergeant Rebecca McKay said she led a “team” of investigators to inspect the claims against Fairey. “My team and myself went out searching for these [unauthorized works],” McKay said. No direct evidence was produced: McKay said none of the building owners witnessed Fairey painting an image, and neither did her officers. “With my eyes, did I see him do it? No, I did not,” McKay said, adding that building owners identified with works tied to Fairey had not approached the city. When officers contacted the building owners, however, at least eight said they wanted to file complaints. It is unclear if prosecutors have video evidence against Fairey. Detroit officials declined a request for comment by the Guardian. “The city does not comment on ongoing litigation,” said Detroit corporation counsel Melvin “Butch” Hollowell, in a statement to the Guardian. “Our position in this matter will be made in court.” While it is unlikely that the city of Detroit will be able to stop street artists producing unauthorized works, the Duggan administration is adamant that investigating “quality of life” crimes is a priority. Such an approach is a key part of so-called “broken windows” policing, under which relatively minor crimes are investigated aggressively and which Detroit has adopted in recent years. “It’s not that we’re going after violent crime; we’re going after all crime,” Detroit police chief James Craig told the Detroit News in July. That level of persistence, and how it has affected Fairey’s case, is “very disappointing”, said Matt Eaton, a partner at the Library Street Collective, a gallery that hosted an exhibition of the artist’s work earlier this year. “It’s hard to imagine this being a source of inspiration for aspiring artists in the city,” Eaton said. “It definitely gives you pause when deciding to move forward with any public arts initiative.” Jesse Cory, co-owner of local gallery and publisher 1xRUN, said Detroit officials were “overreaching”. The prosecution of Fairey “seems to be more of a communication vehicle”, he said, for city officials to say: “‘We’re changing the status quo, starting with this case.’” “Many crimes have been committed for a building to become derelict,” Cory said, “from the original owner not paying property taxes, from the scrappers that went in and pulled out all the copper, or the arsonist that set the place on fire. “The graffiti, or in this case the wheat paste, is the last offense in a series of events for many of the properties that have become a beacon for graffiti.” Cory said, however, that the impact of the Fairey case on the local art community had been limited. If anything, he said, the case had catapulted public art into local dialogue, generating interest in new areas. At a recent mural festival in Detroit’s Eastern Market, which maintains some of the most striking works of public art in the city, Cory said the crowd appeared to come from a “diverse cross section of demographics in age and race from our entire metro area, that [were] just discovering this contemporary public art”. The festival, indeed, featured a work – by New York-based Pursue and Kwest from Toronto and featuring a police car with shackled hands protruding from the back window – that referenced Fairey’s legal battle. Eaton said the city should strive to engage with the arts community for guidance and advice. “Communication is the key here,” he said. “Let’s have a friendly conversation and take a closer look at what constitutes art and how it’s different from vandalism.” The case against Fairey moves along. After prosecutors revealed a spike in the cost of the alleged vandalism, the charges were increased. Fairey is now facing a sentence of up to 10 years, as well as two counts of malicious destruction of a railroad bridge. His attorney, Bradley Friedman, did not respond to requests for comment. Fairey’s next court hearing is set for 10 December. Trial is scheduled for 26 January.
